awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: AST: Collaborative Research: Computational science in support of space missions: plasma turbulence modeling on geodesic meshes
awd_abstract_narration:
In situ and remote observations in the solar wind and other astrophysical environments reveal that the plasma invariably possesses anisotropic temperatures.  This requires non-ideal magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), but so far there has been no consistent approach to modeling the necessary physics.  The most significant open question in heliophysics is to explain the extraordinarily high temperature of the solar corona and hence the origin of the solar wind.  Forthcoming observations should provide a wealth of new information, but interpretation is likely to find current theory considerably wanting.  This project will go beyond the MHD approximation using the most sophisticated computational algorithms and combining the unique strengths of the research team.  The calculational tools developed to analyze solar activity will yield a better understanding of how solar storms arise and thus enhance predictive space weather capabilities.  The research team is heavily involved in the teaching and dissemination of computational physics with significant workforce development impact.

Recent advances in plasma theory provide closures of the fluid hierarchy incorporating anisotropic pressures, reproducing linear Landau damping to any desired precision, and demonstrating convergence of the fluid and collisionless kinetic descriptions.  This work will integrate an advanced description of the coronal and inner heliosphere plasma into models of wave propagation, turbulence transport, and anisotropic heating.  It will enable solution of the Chew-Goldberger-Low (CGL) equations, including a Hall term, on adaptive, spherical meshes with physics-based turbulent closures.  This involves three highly innovative tasks: 1) a correct treatment of the Hall-CGL equations; 2) development of adaptive mesh refinement for spherical meshes; 3) a weakly compressible model for turbulence which enables a physics-based estimate of the transport coefficients for anisotropic thermal conduction in plasmas with anisotropic pressure distributions.  The resulting code will take the astrophysics and space science communities to the next level of sophistication in modeling astrophysical plasmas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project was proposed in response to the realization that several NASA missions, including the Parker Solar Probe, Voyager, and the flotilla of NASA satellites that ring the earth were showing some unexplainable results. All these missions, despite the fact that they explore different regions of the solar system, were all showing a consistent result. They were showing that the rarefied and highly magnetized plasmas that make up our solar environment can often have pressures that are anisotropic. In other words, the pressure parallel to the magnetic field can be substantially different from the pressure perpendicular to the magnetic field. 

 

This result poses a dilemma because the MHD approximation that has been used to model our solar environment posits only an isotropic pressure. As a result, one suspects that most of the modeling work might have been done with a model for the plasma that is "not quite right". In fairness, other models for modeling the rarefied magnetized plasma that permeates our solar environment have always existed. The Chew, Goldberger and Low (CGL) equations for modeling dilute plasmas has always allowed for anisotropic pressure tensors. The only problem is that the CGL equations have proved completely intractable when used for numerical work. As a result, the community did not have a model that could be used for numerical simulations. This proposal took on he task of making it feasible for us to numerically model the CGL equations.

 

The process that went into achieving this result required making advances in applied mathematics as well as physics. On the applied math front, we realized that the CGL equation set was non-conservative. As a result, several new methods were invented for solving PDE systems that are in non-conservative form. However, even the best mathematical innovations did not yield methods for solving the CGL equations. The reason stems from physical realizability. In laymans terms, even if one uses the best mathematical methods for treating the CGL equations, the equations will dodder off and produce physical variables such as densities and pressures that are physically unrealizable! We realized, therefore, that the solution lay in physics!

 

To that end, we realized that the missing piece of physics was the fact that firehose and mirror instabilities, once they are triggered, can act very fast and drive the pressures back to isotropy. This physical insight was then translated back into mathematics. Consequently, we achieved a solution strategy that kept the CGL equations within the domain of physical realizability!

 

Once this advance was made, we have started moving very quickly towards space physics and astrophysics applications. A starringly important piece of data comes from NASA's Voyager program. The Voyager spacecrafts have just recently moved out of the heliosheath and are now floating in the Local Interstellar Medium (LISM). To appreciate the import of that, it is important to realize that these are the first manmade objects that have left our solar system and are now moving freely in the galactic interstellar medium! The Voyagers sent back data that showed us that upon crossing the heliopause they had discovered a plasma depletion layer. In other words, the plasma pressure perpendicular to the magnetic field was larger than the plasma pressure parallel to the magnetic field. So we have started applying our CGL-based numerical capabilities and are beginning to see the first success in simulating the plasma depletion layer that the Voyagers found! (Obtaining such a result is beyond the ken of MHD simulations!)

 

NASA missions are multi-year and multi-billion dollar investments. The broader impact of this project is that with a small investment from NSF, we are now better positioned to extract the full scientific payoff that comes from these very expensive NASA investments!

 

As part of the outreach we also helped some of the poorest communities in our state, in Gary Indiana, with K-12 math education.
